title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
What is this course about?


Getting started (background and setup)
Programming, in R
Introduction to the tidyverse
Importing data into R
Data visualization Design
Data visualization using ggplot2
Data tidying and transformations
Data analysis (modeling, statistics, ML)
Workflows & best practices (reproducibility)
…anything else?

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Why this course?







Wikipedia

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Data science workflow







https://r4ds.hadley.nz/


Programming is the “glue” that binds all of these steps.

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Freedom and empowerment

You are restricted when using “tools” developed by others;
If you learn to create your own “tools”, the possibilities become endless.
You will gain in efficiency and freedom (you can delegate work to computers).
You will better understand the digital world.

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Learning by doing
This is a hands-on course!

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Resources

Hands-On Programming with R
R for Data Science (2e)
R for Psychological Science
Learning Statistics with R
R for Psych

title: Introduction to data science in R
text:
Grading

Attend and participate
Do the assignments
Complete final project

We will cover the content of the Introduction to programming in R course.

title: Course Overview
text:
This is the homepage for Introduction to Data Science in R taught by Prof. Pedro Cardoso-Leite at the University of Luxembourg within the Doctoral Programme in Psychology.
All course materials will be posted here. Note however that this course also has a moodle page.

title: Introduction to Data Science in R
text:
This is the (work in progress) course website for “Introduction to Data Science in R”.
In this course we will cover the following content:

Chapter 1: Programming in R
Chapter 2: Data visualization

Each chapter contains links to slides and possibly other resources.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Title: Introduction to Data Science in R
Instructor: Pedro Cardoso-Leite
Email: pedro.cardosoleite@uni.lu
ECTS Credits: 3
Language: English
Course Type: Workshop/Lab Course

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
Data science is about transforming raw data into understanding. It involves activities such as preprocessing and documenting data, computing summary statistics, plotting meaningful relationships and writing reports.
This course is designed to help you get started in data science using R, RStudio and the Tidyverse – a set of powerful and popular tools commonly used in academia and the industry – and give you the foundation to further progress autonomously in your data analysis journey.
The course involves many hands-on workshops to put your newly acquired knowledge into practice with concrete and relevant use cases.
Although we welcome all levels, this course will focus on students who begin with R and/or the Tidyverse collection of R packages for data science.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, the student should be able to:

Program in R using current best practices
Be familiar with the main steps of a typical data science workflow
Find help when encountering new data science related problems
Use community-standard tools for visualization (ggplot2)
Perform data tidying and transformation (dplyr, tidyr)
Conduct basic modeling and statistical analysis
Create reproducible reports and documentation

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Information
Instructor: Pedro Cardoso-Leite (pedro.cardosoleite@uni.lu)
ECTS: 3
Language: English
Course Type: Workshop/Lab Course
Semester: Whole Year (Winter + Summer)

title: Syllabus
text:
Workload

Total: 15 weeks
Weekly: 3 hours of on-site lectures and workshops + 2 hours of homework
Total Hours: 75 hours of work

title: Syllabus
text:
Evaluation
Type: Course participation and final project

title: Syllabus
text:
Prerequisites

No programming experience is required
Access to a computer with Internet connection

title: Syllabus
text:
Registration
Open to: All Doctoral Candidates
Max Participants: 20

text: In this chapter we will see how to import different types of data files into R. We will also explore data frames and how to access data inside a data frame.

title: Pipes in R
text:
“Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute.” –Harold Abelson


“Good programmers write code that humans can understand.” –Martin Fowler


“Any code of your own that you haven’t looked at for six or more months might as well have been written by someone else.” –Eagleson’s law

title: Pipes in R
text:
Programming is an interface


“What is the square which when taken with ten of its roots will give a sum of thirty nine?”
al-Khwārizmī

\[x^2 + 10x=39\]



From Bret Victor’s, Media for Thinking the Unthinkable.

title: Pipes in R
text:
\[ y = sin(cos(x+3)-4)+1 \]




reading order

\(y\)
\(=\)
\(sin(\)
\(cos(\)
\(x+3)\)
\(-4)\)
\(+1\)


computing order

\(m = x\)
\(m = m + 3\)
\(m = cos(m)\)
\(m = result - 4\)
\(m = sin(m)\)
\(y = m + 1\)

title: Pipes in R
text:
The pipe operator |>
The pipe operator makes it easier to understand the sequence of computations

title: Pipes in R
text:
\[ y = sin(cos(x+3)-4)+1 \]


rewritten using pipes as:

y <- x |>  
      add(3) |>  
      cos() |>  
      add(-4) |>  
      sin() |>  
      add(1)




reading order

\(y\)
\(=\)
\(sin(\)
\(cos(\)
\(x+3)\)
\(-4)\)
\(+1\)


computing order

\(m = x\)
\(m = m + 3\)
\(m = cos(m)\)
\(m = result - 4\)
\(m = sin(m)\)
\(y = m + 1\)

title: Pipes in R
Pipes in R
text:
Note
Change default setting in Rstudio to switch from %>% to |>

When reading data analysis code you can infer:

if you see |> -> likely recent code
if you see %>% -> likely older code
if you see no pipes -> likely obsolete

title: Pipes in R
text:
Exercises
rewrite code from base-style to pipe-style

sqrt(x)
sin(cos(x))
y <- sin(cos(x+3)-4)+1
mean(x, na.rm = True)
ggplot(data = df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()
setdiff(x,y)
